Apa la sangat 44km...[METROTV]
01 Nov 2019, 22:00 by Redzuan Muharam



SEAWAL 6.45 pagi, Syafeza Sauli menunggang motosikal menuju ke Sekolah Kebangsaan (SK) RPS Dala, Gerik, Perak untuk mengajar murid di sekolah berkenaan.
Perjalanan ditempuhi guru berusia 26 tahun itu setiap hari agak berliku kerana perlu melalui jalan tanah merah membabitkan jarak sejauh 44 kilometer dari rumahnya di pekan Gerik.
Begitulah rutin dilalui Syafeza sejak ditugaskan mengajar di sekolah berkenaan bermula Februari lalu dan kegigihan guru muda itu mendapat pujian selepas gambarnya yang terjatuh motosikal ketika melalui jalan berlumpur tular di laman sosial.
Berkongsi pengalamannya, Syafeza berkata, gambar dan video berkenaan diambil rakannya untuk tujuan dokumentasi dan insiden berkenaan dirakam secara spontan.


SYAFEZA bergambar dengan murid SK RPS Dala, Gerik, Perak.

“Memang begitulah rutin dilalui sejak mengajar di sini dan permukaan jalan tidak rata menyebabkan saya tiada pilihan kecuali ke sekolah dengan menunggang motosikal.
“Ikutkan, saya tidak tahu langsung menunggang motosikal, tetapi mengambil inisiatif untuk belajar memandangkan laluan untuk ke sekolah tidak sesuai dilalui kereta melainkan kenderaan pacuan empat roda.
“Laluan berkenaan sunyi dan disebabkan itu, saya perlu mengatur perjalanan dengan bertolak awal selain memakai pakaian bersesuaian demi keselamatan diri.
“Pernah saya tersesat dan lebih enam kali terjatuh motosikal ketika dalam perjalanan ke sekolah walaupun sudah berhati-hati.
“Keadaan itu berlaku tanpa diduga kerana permukaan jalannya sering berubah mengikut keadaan cuaca,” katanya ketika dihubungi Harian Metro, hari ini.
Meskipun begitu, Syafeza gembira kerana dapat menimba pengalaman itu dan rasa bertuah kerana dihantar bertugas di kawasan pedalaman.
Malah, beliau sudah bersiap sedia dengan kemungkinan itu sejak awal lagi kerana menyedari cabaran perlu dihadapi mereka yang bergelar pendidik.
“Sebenarnya, saya tidak rasa terbeban kerana sedar ramai lagi guru berdepan dengan situasi lebih mencabar.
“Disebabkan itu, saya kurang gemar berkongsi pengalaman dilalui di laman sosial dan gambar tular itu dimuat naik rakan.
“Bagi saya, pengalaman sebagai guru amat menyeronokkan lebih-lebih lagi kerana berpeluang mengajar murid Orang Asli yang tinggi budi bahasanya.
“Selagi termampu, saya akan galas tanggungjawab ini dengan sebaiknya walaupun ada segelintir pihak pernah beranggapan saya tidak akan bertahan lama mengajar di kawasan pedalaman kerana cabaran berkenaan,” katanya.


GELAGAT Syafeza menunggang motosikal melalui jalan berlumpur untuk ke sekolah sebelum terjatuh dirakam rakannya dan tular di media sosial.

Is it 44km ... [METROTV]
01 Nov 2019, 22:00 by Redzuan Muharam



At 6.45am, Syafeza Sauli rode a motorcycle to RPS National School in Dala, Gerik, Perak to teach students at the school.
The 26-year-old teacher's daily commute was a bit confusing as he had to travel through a red dirt road about 44 kilometers from his home in Gerik town.
Such has been the routine of Syafeza since being assigned to the school since February and the young teacher's persistence has been praised after a picture of a motorcycle collapsed on a muddy path on social media.
Sharing his experience, Syafeza said the photos and videos were taken by his friend for the purpose of documentation and the incident was recorded spontaneously.


SYAFEZA poses with SK RPS students Dala, Gerik, Perak.

“It has been such a routine since I was teaching here and the surface of the road was uneven so I had no choice but to go to school on a motorcycle.
“Admittedly, I did not know how to ride a motorcycle at all, but took the initiative to learn that the route to school was not a car except for a four-wheel drive vehicle.
“The route was quiet and because of that, I had to arrange the trip by going ahead and wearing appropriate clothes for personal safety.
“I've lost my way and lost my motorcycle six times while on my way to school despite being careful.
"The situation is unpredictable because the surface of the road is constantly changing depending on the weather," he said when contacted by Daily Metro today.
Nevertheless, Syafeza was happy to have the experience and was lucky to be sent to work in the interior.
In fact, he has been prepared for that possibility from the very beginning because he recognizes the challenges facing educators.
“In fact, I don't feel burdened by the fact that many teachers are facing more challenging situations.
“Because of that, I don't like sharing my experiences on social sites and the pictures were uploaded by friends.
“For me, the experience of being a teacher has been a lot of fun especially because it has the opportunity to teach Aboriginal students at their own discretion.
"As much as I can, I will bear this responsibility even though some may have thought that I would not last long in teaching the countryside because of the challenge," he said.


Syafeza was riding his motorcycle on a muddy road to school before his friend fell and was hit on social media.
